image.altText: A crowd of people, some wearing hi-vis vests, gather beside several trucks loaded with covered goods as they emerge from a wall.

items.synopsis: Israel allows trucks carrying food, water and medicine through the southern crossing from Egypt into Gaza, ahead of a potential invasion, the Associated Press reports.

title.children: Rafah crossing opens to allow trucks carrying humanitarian aid into Gaza — as it happened

image.altText: Two women walk with armed guards

items.synopsis: A mother and daughter from the US become the first of about 200 hostages to be released by Islamist group Hamas, who were kidnapped in its attack on south Israel earlier this month.

title.children: Hamas releases American mother and daughter kidnapped during deadly attack, Israel says

image.altText: Headshot photo of Bill Hayden in 1962.

items.synopsis: Once described as the greatest man never to become prime minister, Bill Hayden surrendered a shot at the top job for the sake of Labor Party unity.

title.children: Bill Hayden, former governor-general and Labor luminary, dies aged 90

image.altText: ministers line up on the steps of government house, paul keating centre

items.synopsis: The Labor luminary, who brought in universal healthcare and the single mother's pension under the Whitlam government, has died aged 90.

title.children: 'The greatest man never to have become prime minister': Friends and former rivals pay tribute to Bill Hayden

image.altText: Methamphetamine, otherwise known as Ice

items.synopsis: Next Saturday the ACT's new drug laws will come into effect, meaning people found possessing small quantities of illicit drugs like heroin, ice or cocaine will be cautioned, fined or referred to a drug counselling program instead of being charged.

title.children: The ACT's new drug decriminalisation laws treat addiction as a health issue. How will that help users?

image.altText: fdheli_PalestineRally_2110_13-35-56.18

items.synopsis: Up to 15,000 people took part in Sydney's pro-Palestinian rally, according to NSW Police, as thousands more turn out in other Australian capital cities.

title.children: Colours of Palestinian flag take over streets in Sydney, Brisbane and Perth

image.altText: A nurse smiling in a hospital room.

items.synopsis: The brown brick hospital on the main drag into Bundaberg is an unassuming building, but many locals are still traumatised by what went on here when Jayant Patel, aka Dr Death, was director of surgery.

title.children: When patients started dying at a regional hospital, one nurse risked it all to blow the whistle

image.altText: Policeman in uniform with Victoria Police backdrop

items.synopsis: Victoria Police is warning action will be taken against anyone who uses the Nazi salute in public, now that the gesture has become illegal.

title.children: It is now illegal to use the Nazi salute in Victoria and police are warning they will take action if they see it

image.altText: A police car parked on Old Dookie Road in Shepparton in front of a road closed sign.

items.synopsis: A five-year-old girl and an unborn baby have been killed in a multi-vehicle collision in northern Victoria, police have confirmed. Four adults were injured.

title.children: Unborn baby and five-year-old girl confirmed as victims of fatal crash near Shepparton

image.altText: An old sepia-toned photograph of a man wearing a suit in a wheelchair.

items.synopsis: How did Ahmed Yassin go from a spiritual leader running a charity, to the co-founder of the ferocious political and paramilitary group Hamas?

title.children: Ahmed Yassin was a quadriplegic refugee who ran a charity. How did he end up founding Hamas?

image.altText: Two women smile at the camera

items.synopsis: As several repatriation flights took off from Tel Aviv airport this week, these Australians decided to stay put. Here's why.

title.children: 'I don't want to abandon her': Emma is one of hundreds of Australians who decided to stay when war broke out

image.altText: A man and dog are rescued from flood in inflatable dinghy by high-vis emergency workers

items.synopsis: Gale-force winds and floods are striking several countries in northern Europe as the region endures more heavy rain that forecasters say will continue into the weekend.

title.children: Storm Babet kills at least three people in UK as floods strike northern Europe

image.altText: Politician Jim Jordan wearing blue suit stands with arms folded by himself amidst empty brown leather chairs

items.synopsis: Jim Jordan's quest to become speaker of the US House of Representatives ends as fellow Republicans revoke their support after a third failed vote.

title.children: Donald Trump-backed Jim Jordan's bid to become US speaker ends after embarrassing third defeat in vote

image.altText: A man poses in a shop window in Poland before allegedly stealing jewellery, food and clothing, according to police.

items.synopsis: Police say the man posed motionless until closing time, before robbing a jewellery stand in a Polish shopping centre.

title.children: Polish police arrest man who pretended to be a mannequin before stealing jewellery

image.altText: man with beard in front of giant rock wave

items.synopsis: Noongar man Michael Ward grew up in the area and says just as water helped form the rock, it's now contributing to its changing appearance.

title.children: It was formed 2.7 billion years ago and attracts visitors from across the globe but now Wave Rock is changing

image.altText: The exterior of a NT Police vehicle, as seen from the left hand side.

items.synopsis: Police will allege the 38-year-old ute driver failed to stop after a crash in the Darwin suburb of Howard Springs, in which a 31-year-old motorcyclist was killed.

title.children: Man charged over fatal hit and run in Darwin's rural area

image.altText: Cradle Mountain in winter.

items.synopsis: Tasmania's peak tourism body is seeking an explanation over the introduction of a new visitor fee in the Cradle Mountain national park, which has also prompted anger and outrage from locals.

title.children: 'Absolutely outrageous': Backlash over new Cradle Mountain visitor fee

image.altText: Anthony Albanese frowns during a press conference.

items.synopsis: The Voice campaign and its politics have confirmed we're in new political territory, where there seems little restraint or even regard for the truth — not just by fringe players but players central to our politics, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: The irony at the end of a week when post-Voice politics entered dangerous new territory

image.altText: Two women smiling holding flowers

items.synopsis: While the whereabouts of hundreds of hostages kidnapped by Hamas a fortnight ago remains unknown, a mother and daughter from the US become the first to be released.

title.children: Here’s what we know about the mother and daughter released by Hamas, and what happens next

image.altText: A framed photograph of a man smiling

items.synopsis: Hundreds of people — family, friends, community leaders, and strangers — gather to pay tribute to those who were lost after a bus rolled at a roundabout near Greta in June.

title.children: ​​​​​​​Tributes flow for the 'beautiful ten' at memorial service for Hunter Valley wedding bus crash victims

image.altText: A woman holding up sanitary products in her kitchen

items.synopsis: Along with other cost-of-living pressures, the price of period products at major supermarkets has been steadily increasing.

title.children: 'It takes your dignity away': Australians cut corners on sanitary products to keep up with rising prices

image.altText: High density housing with predominantly dark roofs.

items.synopsis: Urban heat islands are known to drive up ambient temperatures, but could light-coloured roofs be the silver bullet in reducing Australia’s suburban swelter?

title.children: Monument, ironstone, basalt: Why the colour of the nation's roofs is a hot topic

image.altText: A close up of a small green aquatic plant.

items.synopsis: Biosecurity experts are warning the aggressive, invasive weed acts like a blanket over water, dominating everything and reducing oxygen for aquatic animals.

title.children: This popular aquarium plant can be bought for $5, but did you know it's illegal?

image.altText: A composite image of the Blythe Star and one of the survivors, Mick Doleman.

items.synopsis: It has been 50 years since the Blythe Star sank in Australia's unforgiving southern waters. Now, survivor Mick Doleman is telling the full story of how the crew lasted nearly two weeks in hostile seas, and helping give a voice to those who didn't return.

title.children: 10 desperate men, shipwrecked off the harsh Tasmanian coast and left for dead. How did anyone live to tell the tale?

image.altText: A well dressed older woman stands silhouetted in front of a wall of modern artworks

items.synopsis: "This is what every art historian dreams of finding in their lifetime and they never do. Here he is." How art valuer Elizabeth Arthur discovered a brilliant, obsessive mind.

title.children: Discovered after death: A country town maths teacher's 7,000 secret artworks

image.altText: Kaylee McKeown looks agast

items.synopsis: Australian swimmer Kaylee McKeown now holds all three backstroke world records after smashing the 50 metre mark in the Swimming World Cup event in Budapest.

title.children: Kaylee McKeown smashes world record, becoming undisputed backstroke queen

image.altText: Two women wearing activewear sitting on swings, talking and laughing

items.synopsis: The friends I've made later in my life feel like a gift. Time speeds by when we are together, and yet I age backwards when I am with them, writes Virginia Trioli.

title.children: When motherhood threw a grenade at my friendships, I tossed away some poor advice and found a new tribe

image.altText: Pareto phone graphic

items.synopsis: Pareto Phone folds less than two months after the ABC revealed the company had potentially breached Australian privacy laws by keeping donor details for more than a decade.

title.children: Telemarketer at centre of charity cyber hack collapses, putting more than 100 out of work

image.altText: A man and a woman squeeze into the close sleeping quarters of a van with their small staffordshire terrier-cross.

items.synopsis: Kristy Bowman and Kevin Humphrey's move to a home on wheels is no #vanlife adventure — it's a heartbreaking decision made necessary by constant rent rises.

title.children: Swapping bricks and mortar for a home on wheels, this Queensland couple is choosing homelessness

image.altText: a composite image of stills from popular kids shows

items.synopsis: The research is in, and kids' TV really can be one of our earliest lessons in what it means to be Australian. So what were some of the biggest influences on generations past, and which one shaped you?

title.children: Which Aussie kids shows shaped you into the person you are?
